{{Infobox musical artist | name = Valerie Wellington | image = | caption = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Valerie Eileen Hall | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date|1959|11|14|mf=y}}
[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{dda|1993|1|2|1959|11|14|mf=y}}
[[Maywood, Illinois]], United States | instrument = [[Human voice|Vocals]] | genre = [[Chicago blues]], [[electric blues]] | occupation = [[Singer]], [[actor|actress]] | years_active = Late 1970s–1992 | label = [[Flying Fish Records|Flying Fish]] | associated_acts = | website = | notable_instruments = }} '''Valerie Wellington''' (November 14, 1959 – January 2, 1993){{cite web|author=Doc Rock |url=http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1992.html |title=The Dead Rock Stars Club 1992 - 1993 |publisher=Thedeadrockstarsclub.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} was an [[African-American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[electric blues]] singer and actress. Her 1984 album, ''Million Dollar $ecret'', saw her work with [[Sunnyland Slim]], [[Billy Branch]], and [[Magic Slim]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/million-dollar-ecret-mw0000235180/credits |title=Million Dollar $ecret - Valerie Wellington | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} In her early years, Wellington also worked with [[Lee "Shot" Williams]]. In a short career, she switched from [[opera]] to the [[blues]]. ==Biography== She was born '''Valerie Eileen Hall''' in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p570/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Valerie Wellington |author=O'Neal, Jim |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=September 14, 2011}} Wellington trained as an opera singer, graduating from the [[American Conservatory of Music]],{{cite journal |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |year= |title= |journal=[[Jet (magazine)|Jet]] |volume= 83, No. 12 |issue=January 18, 1993 |page=p.56 |publisher=Johnson Publishing Company |doi= |url= |accessdate=September 14, 2011 }} but in 1982 took up singing the blues in her local Chicago [[nightclub|clubs]]. Her work extended to the [[theatre|theater]], where she undertook roles portraying earlier blues singers such as [[Ma Rainey]] and [[Bessie Smith]]. Wellington's opera training enabled her to project her [[human voice|voice]] to theater audiences. She appeared at the 1984 [[San Francisco Blues Festival]], on the bill alongside [[Marcia Ball]] and [[Katie Webster]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sfblues.com/archives/1984/ |title=San Francisco Blues Festival |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Sfblues.com |accessdate=September 14, 2011}} Her recorded work blended the more traditional [[vaudeville]] approach with a contemporary Chicago blues format. Wellington appeared on a limited number of recordings, but her voice was used on several advertisements on both television and radio. Wellington's recording of "[[Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin On]]" was used on the [[soundtrack]] to the 1989 [[film]], ''[[Great Balls of Fire! (film)|Great Balls of Fire!]]'', in which she briefly appeared depicting [[Big Maybelle]].{{cite web |url=http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0920025/ |title=Valerie Wellington |author= |date= |work= |publisher=IMDb.com |accessdate=September 14, 2011}} In the same year, Wellington toured Japan, with [[Carlos Johnson (blues musician)|Carlos Johnson]]. Wellington died of a [[cerebral aneurysm]] in [[Maywood, Illinois]], in January 1993, at the age of 33. She was interred at the [[Restvale Cemetery]] in [[Alsip, Illinois]]. In 1995, [[Rooster Blues]] re-issued ''Million Dollar $ecret''. ==Discography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year || Title || Record label |- | 1984 || ''Million Dollar $ecret'' || style="text-align:center;"|[[Flying Fish Records|Flying Fish]] |- | 1991 || ''Life in the Big City'' || style="text-align:center;"|GBW (Japan) |}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/valerie-wellington-mn0000302905/discography |title=Valerie Wellington | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-31}} ==See also== *[[List of Chicago blues musicians]] *[[List of electric blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.allaboutjazz.com/php/musician.php?id=11262 Allaboutjazz.com] *[http://www.aaregistry.org/historic_events/view/valerie-wellington-belted-out-blues African American Registry at Aaregistry.org] *{{IMDb name|0920025}} *{{findagrave|10666}} {{Persondata | NAME = Wellington, Valerie | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = Hall, Valerie Eileen | SHORT DESCRIPTION = [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[electric blues]] singer and actress | DATE OF BIRTH = November 14, 1959 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], United States | DATE OF DEATH = January 2, 1993 | PLACE OF DEATH = [[Maywood, Illinois]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wellington, Valerie}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:1993 deaths]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:African-American female singers]] [[Category:African-American opera singers]] [[Category:Chicago blues musicians]] [[Category:Electric blues musicians]] [[Category:Deaths from aneurysm]] [[Category:Musicians from Chicago, Illinois]] [[Category:American film actresses]] [[Category:African-American actresses]] [[Category:American musical theatre actresses]] [[Category:20th-century American actresses]]
